springboot_tps_jmx_top_10_kpis.kpi_definition: The percentage of Java heap memory currently in use. High memory usage can lead to garbage collection overhead and OutOfMemory errors, causing transaction failures and system crashes.
The time spent on garbage collection. High GC pressure reduces transaction throughput, increases response times, and indicates memory management issues that can stall transaction processing.
The number of active JVM threads. High thread counts may indicate thread pool exhaustion or blocking operations, which can limit transaction concurrency and cause queue buildup.
The percentage of CPU capacity used by the JVM process. High CPU usage indicates computational bottlenecks that can slow down transaction processing and increase latency.
The percentage of active database connections from the connection pool. High utilization indicates database bottlenecks or long-running transactions that can block new transaction processing.
The rate of garbage collection events per second. High frequency indicates memory pressure and object churn, which can cause transaction processing pauses and inconsistent performance.
The percentage of file descriptors in use. High usage may indicate resource leaks or excessive file/socket operations that can lead to transaction failures when limits are reached.
The time since the JVM process started. Frequent restarts indicate instability, crashes, or deployment issues that disrupt transaction processing continuity.
The time requests spend waiting in thread pool queues. High queue times indicate the system is overwhelmed and cannot process transactions promptly, leading to increased latency.
The rate of new classes being loaded into the JVM. Sudden spikes may indicate memory leaks, dynamic class generation issues, or deployment problems affecting transaction processing.
